title.narrative: Power Up Programme

description.narrative: Power Up! Is a consortium of four women’s right organisations : Just Associates (JASS, lead organisation), Coalition of African Lesbians (CAL), Yayasan Pemberdayaan Perempuan Kepala Keluarga (PEKKA), and Gender at Work (G@W). We will be building, organising, mobilising and transforming power on three strategic agendas, aligned with the Power of women fund’s objectives: 1. Prevention and elimination of sexual and gender-based violence against women and girls – addressed through our bodies agenda. 2. strengthening women’s leadership and women’s participation in (political) decision-making – addressed through our voices agenda.

title.narrative: 2.2 Women express their views and participate in all decision-making

2.2. VOICES: # of times that WROs (disaggregated by women-led, youth-led or other and formal/informal) succeed in creating space for feminist demands and positions on women’s voice, agency, leadership and representative participation in decision- making processes in public, private and civic sphere, through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or movement building.

comment.narrative: As the indicator measures any new values occurring since the start of the intervention, the baseline value is set at 0. Specific details regarding the situation at the start can be found in the narrative baseline report.
The midline target is set at 50% of the endline target.
In 2021, we focused on resources, access and control over resources first.

title.narrative: 5.1. Strengthened and new collaborations with diverse (cross-movement) alliances to support women's leadership and feminist agendas
5.1.1 # of new/diverse alliances created by PU!

comment.narrative: As the indicator measures any new values occurring since the start of the intervention, the baseline value is set at 0. Specific details regarding the situation at the start can be found in the narrative baseline report.
Target is annual, will increase each period

In October 2021, PEKKA together with 10 WROs with experience in organizing women in micro and small business actors formed the Women's Empowerment for Economic Justice Forum. The ten WROs are; Aisyiyah, ASPPUK, Puspita Bahari Cooperative, FAMM, JASS SEA, KOBETA, Annisa KSU, PERMAMPU, PESADA, and PPSW. This forum aimed to seek support for the development of the role of women in realizing a just economy, and campaign for equitable forms of economic enterprise, including; cooperatives, micro business groups and others.
During 2021, the Forum met thrice and agreed on the name of the network, goals and agenda to be carried out, especially in 2022. Forum members have collected data and information on cooperative members and women micro-enterprises who have been our mantra. These materials will be used as material for the campaign to strengthen women's movements for economic justice. The plan is that the Forum will launch a movement by inviting the government, the business sector, and civil society organizations. In addition, the forum will also campaign for equitable forms of economic business, mass media and social media.
Aside from the national level, PEKKA also initiated economic network meetings in 3 regencies/cities namely; Pemalang - Central Java, Bone - South Sulawesi, and Baubau - South East Sulawesi. The organizations involved include Aisyiyah, Fatayat, GOW (Gabungan Organisasi Wanita or Women's Organization Association) and others.

title.narrative: 6.1. Increased actions of women using their collective power to demand rights, increase access to resources and ensure collective safety
6.1.1 # of actions by women supported by PU!

comment.narrative: As the indicator measures any new values occurring since the start of the intervention, the baseline value is set at 0. Specific details regarding the situation at the start can be found in the narrative baseline report.
Target is annual, will increase each period

In order to build public awareness for environmentally friendly behavior and clean living by managing household waste in order to create a healthy and sustainable environment, PEKKA facilitates their cooperatives and associations in 23 districts/cities to develop various community initiatives. This initiative activity began with Pekka Leaders leading a discussion to discuss problems and seek ideas to solve them. Then they agreed on the initiative activities, made plans and did the division of tasks. After the activity was carried out, the PEKKA Leader would present the learning outcomes of the initiative in a meeting with village leaders and government at the district/city level.
In 2021, Pekka Leaders have initiated: - Bank Sampah (The Waste Bank) in 3 regions. The Waste Bank is a movement to collect non-organic waste in the form of plastic, cans, etc at the household level. Then the household will send the waste to the Waste Bank Officer. Furthermore, Pekka Leaders as the manager of the waste bank will sort it out and sell it to other parties to be processed into other useful products. - Black Bags Movement in 4 regions. Black Bag Movement is a village clean-up movement initiated by Pekka Leaders, name of which refers to the black plastic bags often used to contain domestic waste. In this movement, they invited the society, especially women to pick up the waste around their houses and put them in black plastic bags. After the bag is full, Pekka Leaders will send it to the Pekka Waste Bank (if there is any) or the final waste disposal site.
At the same year, PEKKA held Kelas BISA KITA (refers to Kelas Bisnis Berbasis Komunitas or Community-Based Business Class). It was a series of trainings focused on waste management, such as Used Cooking Oil Management, Collective Compost Processing, and Plastic Waste Management. After the workshop finished, Pekka Leaders mobilize Pekka Community to practice as the implementations of what they got in the trainings. - Used Cooking Oil Management: Pekka Community was taught to process used cooking oil into laundry soap that has both usability and marketability. - Collective Compost Processing: Pekka Community was taught to process organic waste into compost that can be used for farming. - Plastic Waste Management: Pekka Community was taught to process inorganic waste (especially plastic) into useful and economic value goods. The plastic waste is usually processed into shopping bags, pencil cases, pouches, etc.

title.narrative: 3.2 Women have access to resources and economic autonomy

3.2. RESOURCES: # of times that WROs (disaggregated by women-led, youth-led or other and formal/informal) succeed in creating space for feminist demands and positions on women’s economic rights, economic justice and alternatives, through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or movement building.

comment.narrative: As the indicator measures any new values occurring since the start of the intervention, the baseline value is set at 0. Specific details regarding the situation at the start can be found in the narrative baseline report.
The midline target is set at 50% of the endline target.

PEKKA has facilitated Pekka Cooperatives and Pekka Associations (WRO) for advocacy activities to the government to provide support for strengthening the local economy through budgets and policies. The advocacy process is carried out through village-level discussions called “Diskusi Kampung” and district-level discussions called “Forum Pemangku Kepentingan” or Stakeholders Forum. The two discussions were formal meetings initiated by PEKKA to discuss various potentials and challenges in strengthening the local economy.
Throughout 2021, PEKKA has organized 26 Stakeholder Forums in 21 districts/cities in 16 provinces attended by 899 people of which 75.2% are women, including the Pekka Community. Pekka Leaders in 23 districts have also held 62 Village Discussions in 61 villages attended by 1,538 people, of which 72.2% are women, including from the Pekka Community. Participants outside the Pekka community are; village government and community leaders, including women and religious leaders. During the meeting, all local governments expressed their support for Pekka activities in strengthening the local economy in the form of programs and other assistance.

title.narrative: 5.2. Strengthened community, national, and regional safety networks to provide support/safety for women in high risk environments
5.2.1 # of safety networks created/supported by PU!

comment.narrative: As the indicator measures any new values occurring since the start of the intervention, the baseline value is set at 0. Specific details regarding the situation at the start can be found in the narrative baseline report.
Target is annual, will increase each period

PEKKA is an organization that uses a community organizing approach and in the last 20 years has organized 31,447 members who are members of 2,559 groups at the village level by implementing a cooperative model. Meanwhile, The Our Bodies, Our Lives Campaign (OBOL) movement has led 8,000 actions by mobilizing HIV+ positive women (they live in rural areas) in Malawi. In order to expand the achievements of PEKKA and OBOL, JASS facilitates an exchange of experiences and learning sessions with a focus on building collective strength through women's cooperatives.
This activity was held in November 2021 and there were 14 people from PEKKA and PEKKA community who joined the event, where they shared their experiences through the Zoom platform for about 4 hours.

title.narrative: 6.2 Increased visibility of women's experiences, leadership, perspectives, solutions and demands
6.2.1 # of times women’s experiences, leadership perspectives, solutions and demands reflected in Power Up! communication products.

comment.narrative: As the indicator measures any new values occurring since the start of the intervention, the baseline value is set at 0. Specific details regarding the situation at the start can be found in the narrative baseline report.
Target is annual, will increase each period

PEKKA trains Pekka Leaders in the community to write down their experiences in leading the implementation of activities, from village level to district level in the form of popular writing. After editing, the articles would be published in bulletins, social media and the PEKKA portal. In addition to these written materials, PEKKA also includes sharing experiences and lessons learned in organizing women-headed family in Indonesia through website, social media, and other materials.
During 2021, there are 104 articles by 37 Pekka journalists who are actively writing and have been published in 15 bulletins from 13 districts in Indonesia. The writings are mostly about the inspirational story of Pekka members, the activities that have been done by the Pekka communities, and opinion writings to respond to social issues. PEKKA also uploaded 112 contents on Facebook, 184 contents on Instagram, and created >5 presentation materials related to experiences and learning.

title.narrative: 6.3. Women's collectives/ groups create feminist economic alternatives
6.3.1 # of economic initiatives developed by women's collectives/groups as a result of PU! interventions

comment.narrative: As the indicator measures any new values occurring since the start of the intervention, the baseline value is set at 0. Specific details regarding the situation at the start can be found in the narrative baseline report.
Target is annual, will increase each period

Since 2002, PEKKA has been organizing poor women-headed family through the growth of savings and loan groups using the cooperative method. This method aims to change behavior and way of thinking, from initially expecting help from outside, to relying on one's own abilities. Even though it is slow, collectively, the savings assets of the Pekka community continue to grow and develop into a sustainable alternative source of finance at the village to district/city level. Furthermore, the capital collected in the Pekka Savings and Loans Cooperative (PEKKA-SIMPIN) is managed by the management for the welfare of members by developing business units: - PEKKA-MART (Grocery Store units); Wholesale center for the procurement of basic materials and production materials for members, as well as marketing products from other business units. - PEKKA-PRODUCTION (Producing units); Collective efforts that produce basic needs such as; food, clothing, and boards with local materials that are around them. - Member Retail Business Unit; personal business managed by Pekka members. This business is a PEKKA-MART network to reach a wider range of consumers. - PEKKA-CBT, a Community Based Travel Business Unit (CBT) is a business managed by Pekka with youth groups by developing cultural tourism packages including stories of Pekka's and community's lives.
In order to expand its network, PEKKA started to gather and organize women-headed families and made a group with savings and loans as the main activity. After the group has been created, PEKKA will conduct them to choose the cooperative's administrators, and they will determine the number of deposits. Deposits here are not only in the form of money but also in the form of goods. These goods will then be sold to other parties so that the cash from the sale can be used as their capital for activities.
In addition, PEKKA also provides training for cooperative administrators, one of which is Training of Trainers (ToT) activities, and provides community assistance (such as group meeting activities, discussions related to the economy and civil rights, etc.). After community training and mentoring activities have been carried out by PEKKA to the community, the cooperative administrators can invite the people who meet PEKKA's member requirements to join the Pekka Community, so that the network will get bigger and community activities are also more diverse, not stopping at Savings and Loans Cooperative or PEKKA-SIMPIN.
And in 2021, there are 31 PEKKA-SIMPIN (Savings and Loan Cooperatives), 31 PEKKA-MART (Grocery Store units), and 72 PEKKA-PRODUCTION (Producing units) in 19 districts/cities in 15 provinces in Indonesia.

title.narrative: 5.3. Increased feminist solidarity and urgent action responses
5.3.1 # solidarity/urgent actions supported by PU!

comment.narrative: As the indicator measures any new values occurring since the start of the intervention, the baseline value is set at 0. Specific details regarding the situation at the start can be found in the narrative baseline report.
Target is annual, will increase each period

Since its initiation in 2012, PEKKA and other WROs advocate to goverment and parliament to immediately pass the Legal Draft on the Elimination of Criminal Acts of Sexual Violence. This law is very much needed, because PEKKA has received case reports of women, including girls, who have been victims of sexual violence. It is hoped that this law will provide extra protection to victims. PEKKA's involvement includes discussions among WROs and lobbying to the government and parliamentarians at the national level.
Moreover, in December 2021, Pekka Community organizations (WRO) in 24 regencies/cities were also involved in the Istighosah Akbar (joint prayer) activity to support the ratification of the Sexual Violence Bill which is being discussed in the House of Representatives. The event was attended by 575 people and involved community leaders including Muslim, Christian and Hindu religious leaders.

title.narrative: 4.2. Enhanced capacity of WROs to design and implement effective strategies and articulate collective political agendas
4.2.1. # of WROs' (political and technical capacities) strengthened by PU!

comment.narrative: As the indicator measures any new values occurring since the start of the intervention, the baseline value is set at 0. Specific details regarding the situation at the start can be found in the narrative baseline report.
Target is annual, will increase each period

Through training and mentoring, PEKKA has trained Pekka Cooperatives and Pekka Associations (WROs) in managing their organizations, building networks and advocating to the government. In managing the organization, PEKKA trains those administrators to make financial and narrative reports on a regular basis, and every year they must report the progress of their activities to members and stakeholders at the local level through the Annual Membership Meeting.
In addition, PEKKA also trains and assists the management of Pekka Cooperatives and Pekka Associations (WROs) to attend official meetings in villages and districts. They also invited stakeholders to be actively involved in the Village Discussions and Stakeholders Forums they held. In the meeting, Pekka Leaders will share their experiences and lessons learned in developing cooperatives and the challenges they face as well as submit proposals to the government for economic justice. PEKKA's way of advocating has been appreciated by the governments at the village and district levels.

title.narrative: 4.1 Increased leadership capacity and organising skills of women to bring about change in their lives and communities
4.1.1b # women (non-youth) who report increased confidence, political skills and consciousness as a result of PU! interventions

comment.narrative: As the indicator measures any new values occurring since the start of the intervention, the baseline value is set at 0. Specific details regarding the situation at the start can be found in the narrative baseline report.
Target is annual, will increase each period

Capacity building is carried out at the national, district/city level, and also at the local level. At the national level, Pekka Community participated in a webinar held to commemorate International Women's Day. In this event, the Minister of Cooperatives also gave a keynote speech and appreciated PEKKA for encouraging the economic movement through the formation of cooperatives in various parts of Indonesia.
In addition, there is also Kelas BISA KITA (refers to Kelas Bisnis Berbasis Komunitas or Community-Based Business Class), where PEKKA provides training to the Pekka Community on how to process organic waste and household waste into compost, make soap from used cooking oil, and process inorganic waste into products with economic value. This activity was attended by 139 people from 23 districts.
At the district/city level, capacity building was carried out intensively in 32 districts in 17 provinces. The training method at the district/city level used the training for trainer method where the potential Pekka Leaders trained in class. Then on the second day, they practiced to lead discussions in groups. On the third day, Pekka Leaders gathered in class again to reflect on the results of the practice, including taking important lessons.
There is also capacity building at the district/city level carried out by the Paradigta Academy (Classes of "Women Lead Everyone A Changemaker"), which aims to develop women's leadership in families, communities and rural communities to become reformers and bring forth the young generation of reformers. The education method is carried out by holding classes which are attended by highly potential village women with a number of participants between 20-35 people per class. Classes are held 2 - 4 times a week for 4-5 hours/meeting. In addition to discussing materials in class, discussion assignments at the family level, discussions with other families, young people, and discussions and action plans with village communities are also given. Another method is to create a WhatsApp group consisting of an Education Coordinator, mentor and participants as a forum for deepening material and discussing other things. A total of 648 participants came from 7 provinces and 15 districts. A total of 340 participants took classes that were fully funded by the Power Up program and 308 people attended classes whose implementation was funded partially by Power Up! and the local government, especially Kubu Raya Regency, West Kalimantan.
Then at the local level, throughout 2021, Pekka Leaders have facilitated group discussions in 71 villages, 33 sub-districts, 11 districts which were attended by 1,559 women. Topics of group discussion include; the importance of saving, forms of saving, the policy of the Village Minister on the use of village funds for women's empowerment, circular economy, local economic movements, and others.

title.narrative: 4.3 Women are equipped with tools, methods, research, evidence and learning from practice to inform strategy and action

4.3.1b # of feminist knowledge products (including tools and methodologies) on power, feminist movement building strategy and feminist analysis of bodies, voices and resources created by PU! to women (non-youth)

comment.narrative: As the indicator measures any new values occurring since the start of the intervention, the baseline value is set at 0. Specific details regarding the situation at the start can be found in the narrative baseline report.
Target is annual, will increase each period

PEKKA manages knowledge products of economic movement by documenting experiences in the form of writings, photos, videos and others. These materials have been used as a guide for discussions at the village, district and national levels. Several writings of Pekka Community Journalists that have been written in bulletins have been used as advocacy materials.
Throughout 2021, PEKKA developed 14 guidelines and 15 bulletins in 13 districts. Three Pekka Leaders teams in 3 districts have also made 3 community videos. The three community videos contain; village discussion, making Batik with ecoprint method, and coconut oil production. The three community videos are currently in the editing process.
In addition, there was also knowledge management carried out by Paradigta Academy (Classes of "Women Lead Everyone A Changemaker"), which aimed to document experiences and lessons learned from classroom management. Knowledge in the form of modules consisting of 3, namely: Module 1: I, Leadership and Change; Module 2: We are a Family of Changemakers; Module 3: We are a Changemaking Community. Documentations are in the form of videos explaining the Paradigta Academy Education program and a video documentation of the implementation of the Paradigta Academy classes in 2021. Both videos are used as learning media.

title.narrative: 2.1 Women express their views and participate in all decision-making

2.1. VOICES: # of laws, policies and strategies blocked, adopted or improved to promote women’s voice, agency, leadership and solutions, and representative participation in decision-making processes in public, private and civic sphere.

comment.narrative: As the indicator measures any new values occurring since the start of the intervention, the baseline value is set at 0. Specific details regarding the situation at the start can be found in the narrative baseline report.

At the midline, it is expected that 50% of all country targets of this indicator have been reached. For IATI, this indicator will show the 5 year target both for midline and endline as it cannot be predicted in advance which ones will be completed.
